comparison_metadata.purpose: Assess extraction quality differences between PDF and plain text sources

project_metadata.paper_title: Identifying accurate artefact morphological ranges using optimal linear estimation: Method validation, case studies, and code
project_metadata.journal: Journal of Archaeological Science, Vol. 162, Article 105921
project_metadata.research_context: Validation and application of optimal linear estimation (OLE) modelling to reconstruct complete morphological ranges of archaeological artefacts from fragmentary excavated datasets. Tests method validity using replica stone tool assemblages with known complete distributions, then applies OLE to ten archaeological case studies covering lithic, ceramic, and metal artefacts produced by humans, extinct hominins, and non-human primates.

evidence.evidence_text: Validation tests using replica handaxe assemblage (n=500) showed combined CI coverage of 0.906 across all sampling conditions
evidence.verbatim_quote: For the handaxe replica assemblage (n = 500), combined results produced CI coverage of 0.906, with 0.919 and 0.893 for the minimum and maximum estimates, respectively.

evidence.evidence_text: Validation tests using Early Archaic points (n=30) showed combined CI coverage of 0.930
evidence.verbatim_quote: The small EAP assemblage (n = 30) displayed a combined CI coverage of 0.930, with minimum and maximum estimates at 0.908 and 0.952, respectively.

evidence.evidence_text: Higher sampling percentages (larger sample sizes) generally produced higher CI coverages
evidence.verbatim_quote: Higher sampling percentages (i.e., larger sample sizes) generally produced higher CI coverages (Fig. 5A and B; Supplementary Tables 1 and 2).

evidence.evidence_text: At 5% sampling (25 artefacts from 500), handaxe CI coverage dropped to 0.727
evidence.verbatim_quote: at 5% (i.e., 25 artefacts) this drops to 0.727.

evidence.evidence_text: At 10% sampling (50 artefacts from 500), median CI coverage was 0.765
evidence.verbatim_quote: the available estimate for a range limit given the artefacts available and median CI coverage of 0.765.

evidence.evidence_text: k=5 and k=10 records performed well in validation tests
evidence.verbatim_quote: Our results are consistent with these earlier studies, with 5–10 records performing well (Fig. 5C and D).

evidence.evidence_text: Archaeological case studies showed morphometric range extensions of 3-63%
evidence.verbatim_quote: morphometric ranges were increased by 3–63%, depending on the case study and attribute investigated

evidence.evidence_text: Old Park flakes showed range extensions of 15-36% depending on attribute
evidence.verbatim_quote: OLE increased this variability by 15%–36%, depending on the morphometric attribute investigated.

evidence.evidence_text: Old Park flake mass range extended from 0.2-40.2g to approximately 0.06-55g
evidence.verbatim_quote: For example, flake mass – at least for the technological strategies discovered so far (as there could be others [e.g., Sharon, 2010]) – should no longer be considered to vary from 0.2 to 40.2 g, but instead likely ranges from ~0.06 to 55 g.

evidence.evidence_text: Boxgrove handaxe mass showed limited range extension (11.9%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Although some Boxgrove range extensions were limited (e.g., mass at 11.9%), OLE estimated there to be considerable undiscovered shape diversity.

evidence.evidence_text: Boxgrove PC1 and PC2 shape variables predicted to increase by 47% and 24%
evidence.verbatim_quote: PC1 and PC2 are predicted to increase by 47% and 24%, respectively.

evidence.evidence_text: Sibudu bipolar cores showed limited range extensions (3.3-17.2%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: The Sibudu bipolar core's more limited range extensions (3.3–17.2%) result from there being multiple tightly constrained records at the upper and lower limits of each variable.

evidence.evidence_text: Copper socketed tang point breadth showed 62.9% range extension (second largest)
evidence.verbatim_quote: In sharp contrast is copper socketed tang point breadth, which displays the second largest range extension across all case studies (62.9%; Table 5).

evidence.evidence_text: Copper point breadth extension resulted from single outlier 15mm greater than next widest
evidence.verbatim_quote: This breadth increase results almost entirely from a 24 mm range increase at the upper limit of these tools, which itself results from a single outlier more than 15 mm greater than the next widest artefact

evidence.evidence_text: Middle Historic and Neolithic ceramic rim diameter extensions were similar (40.7% and 42.3%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: both ceramic types had their range similarly extended (40.7% and 42.3% for the Middle Historic and Neolithic Impressed Ware, respectively).

evidence.evidence_text: Eastern Clovis maximum length extended from 151mm to 211mm (60mm increase)
evidence.verbatim_quote: the modelled Clovis point maximum length being 243 mm, while the estimated maximum size of Eastern Clovis points is now 211 mm, 60 mm longer than previously thought.

evidence.evidence_text: Difference between Clovis and Eastern Clovis maximum length reduced from 75mm to 32mm after OLE
evidence.verbatim_quote: Prior to the present paper there was a 75 mm difference between the largest evidenced Eastern Clovis point (151 mm) and the largest Clovis point (231 mm). The OLE estimates reduced this difference substantially

evidence.evidence_text: Removal of duplicate data revealed little impact on OLE estimates
evidence.verbatim_quote: The removal of duplicate data is revealed to have little impact on OLE estimates (Table 7).

evidence.evidence_text: Minimum estimates showed higher CI coverage than maximum estimates, with minimum values displaying steeper distributions in both validation assemblages
evidence.verbatim_quote: It potentially also explains the greater CI coverage demonstrated by the minimum range estimates of both handaxes and EAPs compared to maximum estimates (Fig. 4). Indeed, minimum values for variables in both tool types displayed steeper distributions (Supplementary Figs. 1 and 2).

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both items describe the same phenomenon (distribution shape affects CI coverage) and support the same claim (C014). Combined verbatim quote preserves full context from both locations.

evidence.evidence_text: Replica handaxe assemblage comprised 500 handaxes produced by single knapper
evidence.verbatim_quote: The replica handaxe assemblage is comprised of 500 handaxes produced by one of us (SJL) via hard hammer direct percussion.

evidence.evidence_text: Early Archaic Points comprised 30 complete points representing 'known' assemblage
evidence.verbatim_quote: The second validation assemblage is comprised of 30 complete Early Archaic Points (EAP) digitized from Justice (1987).

evidence.evidence_text: Ten archaeological case studies spanning lithic, ceramic, and metal artefacts
evidence.verbatim_quote: Ten archaeological case studies, covering lithic, ceramic, and metal artefacts, are investigated to test the method's archaeological potential

evidence.evidence_text: OLE extended handaxe metric ranges by 3-36% in validation tests
evidence.verbatim_quote: In our validation tests, OLE extended handaxe metric ranges by 3–36% (Table 4)

evidence.evidence_text: Negative relationship between sample size and range extension percentage
evidence.verbatim_quote: when removed, result in a negative relationship between range extension percentage and sample size (B).

evidence.evidence_text: OLE is a frequentist statistical technique able to estimate upper and lower range boundaries
evidence.verbatim_quote: optimal linear estimation – a frequentist statistical technique able to estimate the upper and lower range boundaries of Weibull-distributed linear phenomena

claims.claim_text: OLE can accurately estimate morphological ranges of archaeological artefacts from fragmentary datasets
claims.verbatim_quote: Validation tests using replica artefact assemblages demonstrate OLE to vary in accuracy depending on the number of records entered into the model, and the percentage of the original artefact sample available for investigation. Although more experimental testing and method validation are needed and encouraged (Eren et al., 2016a,b), the method is suggested to provide broadly accurate estimates for the morphological range of artefacts.

claims.claim_text: Combined CI coverage of 0.906 for handaxe validation indicates broadly accurate OLE estimates
claims.verbatim_quote: For the handaxe replica assemblage (n = 500), combined results produced CI coverage of 0.906, with 0.919 and 0.893 for the minimum and maximum estimates, respectively.

claims.claim_text: OLE can be used in conditions with highly fragmentary datasets
claims.verbatim_quote: While archaeologists will very rarely know the complete (original) size of an artefact assemblage, it is clear that OLE can be used in conditions with highly fragmentary datasets.

claims.claim_text: As large a sample size as possible should be used for OLE modelling
claims.verbatim_quote: It was revealed that as large a sample size as possible should be used, but estimates remain broadly accurate with samples as low as 5–10% of the original 'complete' assemblage.

claims.claim_text: Optimal number of records (k) for OLE model is approximately 5-10
claims.verbatim_quote: The optimal number of records (k) entered into the model is approximately 5–10 (with a compromise of k = 8 appearing suitable).

claims.claim_text: OLE has potential to alter or overhaul understanding of artefact morphological variation
claims.verbatim_quote: Results varied highly between each case study, but it is clear that OLE has potential to alter, or in some cases overhaul, our understanding of artefact morphological variation in the past.

claims.claim_text: Smallest and largest flakes produced during knapping have not yet been excavated at Old Park
claims.verbatim_quote: This does not change our understanding of how or why these flakes were produced. Instead, it suggests the smallest and largest flake artefacts produced by this hominin population(s) have not yet been excavated

claims.claim_text: Boxgrove handaxes have more diverse forms than previously recognised despite strong ovate central tendencies
claims.verbatim_quote: This does not mean that Boxgrove does not display strong ovate central tendencies (Roberts and Parfitt, 1999; Lycett and von Cramon-Taubadel, 2015; Hosfield et al., 2018; García-Medrano et al., 2019), but rather, there are likely far more diverse forms being produced by these H. heidelbergensis s.l. individuals than previously recognised

claims.claim_text: Sibudu bipolar core sample provides near-accurate representation of actual core variability, with tightly constrained records suggesting strong pressures beyond morphological limits
claims.verbatim_quote: This suggests the artefact sample to provide a near-accurate representation of the core variability produced by these Middle Stone Age humans. At the same time, tightly constrained records before a morphological limit also suggest the presence of strong pressures beyond these limits.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both claims interpret the same Sibudu bipolar core evidence (E012) and form complementary parts of the same interpretive argument. Combined into single compound claim preserving both aspects.

claims.claim_text: Large sample sizes are needed to capture outliers that drive morphological tail estimates
claims.verbatim_quote: This reinforces the need to use as large an artefact sample as possible when using OLE, and the need to visualise data distributions to accurately understand OLE estimates.

claims.claim_text: Both wheel-thrown and hand-built ceramics can introduce similar rim diameter variability despite different production processes
claims.verbatim_quote: What the OLE modelling instead reflects is the shared ability of both processes to introduce rim diameter variability via cultural evolutionary mechanisms (Mesoudi, 2011; Lycett, 2015), even if this is at varying frequencies.

claims.claim_text: OLE substantially reduced the previously claimed size difference between Clovis and Eastern Clovis points
claims.verbatim_quote: The OLE estimates reduced this difference substantially, with the modelled Clovis point maximum length being 243 mm, while the estimated maximum size of Eastern Clovis points is now 211 mm, 60 mm longer than previously thought. This substantially reduces the strength of any claimed size difference between these point types

claims.claim_text: Removal of duplicate data has little impact on OLE estimates
claims.verbatim_quote: The removal of duplicate data is revealed to have little impact on OLE estimates (Table 7).

claims.claim_text: OLE estimates are more accurate for samples with low kurtosis and short distribution tails
claims.verbatim_quote: OLE estimates are, therefore, likely more accurate if samples display relatively low standard deviations, low kurtosis, and consequently comparatively short distribution tails.

claims.claim_text: Archaeologists rarely find complete artefact assemblages, and missing forms are typically at morphometric range extremes due to low production frequency
claims.verbatim_quote: Archaeologists rarely find complete artefact assemblages. That is, sets of archaeological artefacts often do not represent the total cultural – and therefore behavioural – variation of past populations. In artefact morphometric studies, this inevitably leads to the conclusion that some artefact forms created in the past remain unknown. Usually, these forms would be at the extreme ends of morphometric ranges as they would have been infrequently produced in the past.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both theoretical claims form a single argumentative chain (incomplete recovery → missing extremes) from the same location. Combined preserves logical flow and both support patterns.

claims.claim_text: OLE is used to model morphological extremes, not common artefact forms
claims.verbatim_quote: It is worth emphasising that OLE is used here to model morphological extremes. The artefact forms identified in this study would not have been common in the past; quite the contrary, the frequency with which they were produced would have been incredibly low.

claims.claim_text: Identifying morphological extremes reveals limits of what is anatomically and cognitively possible
claims.verbatim_quote: It potentially reveals the absolute limits of what is anatomically and cognitively possible by humans, extinct hominins and non-human primates.

claims.claim_text: Higher resolution morphometric data should be collected to avoid duplication issues
claims.verbatim_quote: a more accurate method would have been to collect higher resolution morphometric data in the first instance (e.g., to three or more decimal places).

claims.claim_text: Distribution shape (kurtosis) affects OLE accuracy more than absolute sample size in some conditions, as demonstrated by the small EAP assemblage's unexpectedly adequate performance
claims.verbatim_quote: The adequate performance of the small EAP sample was to a degree surprising as we had anticipated that records from the tail opposing the one being modelled, or the distribution's peak, could have occasionally (as part of the random sampling) contributed to estimates. Reasoning for this difference relative to the handaxes may lie in the distribution of each sample's data. The handaxe variables (particularly their upper range) typically displayed greater kurtosis, with records being taken from this long tail, while the EAP data displayed steeper distribution curves and relatively reduced kurtosis

consolidation_metadata.rationale: C020 (EAP surprise) and C021 (distribution shape explanation) form a single interpretive argument. C020 presents the observation, C021 provides the explanation. Combined into single claim preserving both elements.

claims.claim_text: More experimental testing and method validation of OLE are needed and encouraged
claims.verbatim_quote: Although more experimental testing and method validation are needed and encouraged (Eren et al., 2016a,b), the method is suggested to provide broadly accurate estimates for the morphological range of artefacts.

claims.claim_text: Geometric microlith differences between phases A and B largely reflect past behaviour accurately
claims.verbatim_quote: There are no examples of morphological differences between the two geometric microlith samples altering substantially as a result of the OLE modelling. This supports the assertion that artefactual differences between phase A and B are a largely accurate reflection of past behaviour

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Weibull distribution is an appropriate model for archaeological artefact morphometric data
trigger_text: optimal linear estimation – a frequentist statistical technique able to estimate the upper and lower range boundaries of Weibull-distributed linear phenomena
morphometric data from ten archaeological case studies, covering lithic, ceramic and metal artefacts produced by humans, extinct hominins and non-human primates, were investigated
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: OLE's validity depends on data following Weibull distribution. Paper applies method to diverse artefact types without explicitly testing distribution fit for each case study, implicitly assuming Weibull adequacy across different production processes and materials.
implicit_arguments.assessment_implications: If artefact data does not follow Weibull distribution, OLE estimates may be systematically biased. This assumption is critical but not empirically tested for each case study.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Replica assemblages produced by modern knappers are representative of actual prehistoric production variability
trigger_text: The replica handaxe assemblage is comprised of 500 handaxes produced by one of us (SJL) via hard hammer direct percussion
Validation tests using replica artefact assemblages demonstrate OLE to vary in accuracy
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Validation relies on replica assemblages as ground truth, but modern knapper production patterns may not reflect prehistoric variability. Single knapper (SJL) produced all 500 handaxes, potentially limiting variability compared to multiple prehistoric producers.
implicit_arguments.assessment_implications: If replica assemblages underrepresent prehistoric variability, validation may overestimate OLE accuracy. The single-knapper design may not capture inter-individual variation present in archaeological assemblages.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Published morphometric datasets accurately represent the excavated assemblages they derive from
trigger_text: morphometric data from ten archaeological case studies
Case study data referenced from published sources (Key and Lycett 2017, de la Peña and Wadley 2014, etc.)
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: OLE is applied to published datasets without independent verification. Measurement protocols, completeness criteria, and selection biases in source publications are inherited without explicit acknowledgment.
implicit_arguments.assessment_implications: Systematic biases in source publications (e.g., excluding broken specimens, measurement error) would propagate to OLE estimates. Data quality of underlying sources is assumed but not verified.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Fragmentary archaeological recovery is the primary cause of missing morphological extremes
trigger_text: Archaeologists rarely find complete artefact assemblages
some artefact forms created in the past remain unknown. Usually, these forms would be at the extreme ends of morphometric ranges as they would have been infrequently produced
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Paper assumes missing extremes are due to sampling/recovery, but alternatives exist: taphonomic destruction of extreme forms, behavioural avoidance of extremes, or transport of extreme tools elsewhere. OLE estimates assume extremes existed but weren't recovered.
implicit_arguments.assessment_implications: If morphological extremes never existed (behavioural constraints) or were systematically destroyed (differential preservation), OLE estimates may model artefacts that never existed rather than 'missing' artefacts.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: CI coverage is the appropriate metric for evaluating OLE accuracy
trigger_text: combined results produced CI coverage of 0.906
The small EAP assemblage (n = 30) displayed a combined CI coverage of 0.930
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Paper uses CI coverage as primary validation metric without discussing alternative metrics (e.g., mean absolute error, bias direction). CI coverage >0.90 is implicitly treated as 'accurate enough' without explicit threshold justification.
implicit_arguments.assessment_implications: CI coverage measures frequency of true values within estimated bounds but not precision of estimates. High coverage with wide intervals may be less useful than lower coverage with narrow intervals for archaeological interpretation.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Range extension percentages are meaningful for archaeological interpretation
trigger_text: morphometric ranges were increased by 3–63%, depending on the case study
OLE has potential to alter, or in some cases overhaul, our understanding of artefact morphological variation
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Paper assumes extending morphometric ranges has interpretive value, but significance depends on what range extension means behaviourally. A 63% extension in one dimension may or may not represent meaningful behavioural/cognitive difference.
implicit_arguments.assessment_implications: Without explicit thresholds for 'meaningful' range extension, claims about OLE's archaeological value rest on implicit assumptions about what magnitude of extension matters for interpretation.

research_designs.design_text: Method validation design using replica assemblages with known complete distributions to test OLE accuracy under controlled conditions
research_designs.verbatim_quote: To better understand the ability of OLE to estimate the full range of a morphological trait, it was necessary to test the model within a context where all artefactual units produced by a population are known – a feat that is impossible in almost all archaeological contexts. To circumnavigate this issue, we use modern assemblages of replica artefacts as this allows random subsamples from a much larger, known distribution of artefacts to be created.

research_designs.design_text: Archaeological case study design applying OLE to ten diverse case studies spanning lithic, ceramic, and metal artefacts
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Ten case studies are investigated here to understand how OLE influences our understanding of the archaeological record under diverse assemblage conditions (Fig. 2). Case studies cover tools produced or used by Holocene humans (Homo sapiens), Early-to-Late Pleistocene hominins (H. erectus, H. heidelbergensis s.l., Homo sapiens) and bearded capuchins (Sapajus libidinosus).

research_designs.design_text: Method repurposing design: adapting OLE from temporal extinction modelling to morphometric range estimation
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Here, we repurpose optimal linear estimation (OLE) modelling, a statistical technique used to reconstruct origination and cessation dates for artefact phenomena (Key et al., 2021a), for a new methodological use: reconstructing the full morphological range of human, extinct hominin and non-human primate artefacts.

research_designs.design_text: Comparative validation design: comparing OLE performance across large (500 handaxes) versus small (30 points) assemblages
research_designs.verbatim_quote: To understand how OLE may function when faced with a much smaller 'complete' assemblage of artefacts, we also investigated morphometric data from 45 replica Early Archaic points (Fig. 2).

research_designs.design_text: Blind test design: using replica assemblages produced before study conception to ensure validation results are not biased by foreknowledge
trigger_text: Importantly, the replica assemblages were produced before the present study was conceived, and thus serve as a blind test.
research_designs.inference_reasoning: The paper mentions blindness as a property of the validation but does not explicitly state it as a design objective in the study's aims. The rationale for why blindness matters (preventing foreknowledge bias) is implied but not articulated as a methodological design choice.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Design rationale for blind testing not explicitly stated. No discussion of how blindness was maintained or verified during analysis.
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Minor - the claim of blindness is plausible but unverified process.

research_designs.design_text: Sample size-range extension relationship investigation: systematic analysis of how assemblage size correlates with OLE range extension percentages
trigger_text: Larger artefact samples generally resulted in more limited range extensions (Fig. 6B).
When results from multiple artefact types are pooled, and sample size and range extension are correlated, these relationships become apparent (Fig. 6).
We were keen to include case studies with diverse sample sizes, to explore how estimates may be influenced by the fragmentedness of a dataset.
research_designs.inference_reasoning: The paper systematically investigates and reports sample size vs range extension correlations with dedicated figure and discussion, but this is not stated as a design objective in the Introduction or Methods. The correlational analysis emerges in Results without being framed as a planned analytical design.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Correlational analysis design not stated in Methods. Unknown whether sample size relationship was a pre-planned investigation or post-hoc observation.
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Moderate - affects interpretation of whether findings were hypothesis-driven or data-driven.

methods.method_text: Optimal Linear Estimation (OLE) modelling using Weibull distribution fitting to estimate upper and lower morphological range boundaries
methods.verbatim_quote: Fundamentally, the method uses the spacing (intervals) and distribution of data points on a linear scale to make predictions about the upper or lower limits of an investigated phenomenon on that scale. It does this by fitting a Weibull distribution curve to these data and the end-point of this distribution marking the estimated start or end of the investigated phenomenon (Fig. 1).

methods.method_text: Random subsampling validation method: creating fragmentary subsamples from known complete distributions at varying sampling percentages
methods.verbatim_quote: The replica handaxe assemblage was randomly subsampled at rates of 5%, 10%, 20%, and 50% relative to the total number of records in the assemblage. These randomly created subsamples were then entered into the OLE model, with only the k (5, 10, 20, or 30) largest or smallest values being used.

methods.method_text: CI coverage assessment method: measuring how often confidence intervals include the true range boundaries across iterations
methods.verbatim_quote: In addition, we apply the approach of Rivadeneira et al. (2009) which investigates how often confidence intervals include or span over the true end of a reconstructed range (i.e, in the case of simulated, complete ranges of morphological attributes, their true maximum and minimum values) across the 1000 iterations. A perfect coverage would be one that is equal to 1-alpha (with alpha of 0.05 used here).

methods.method_text: Duplicate handling method: automatic removal of records with equal values before validation analyses
methods.verbatim_quote: OLE does not work when records with equal values are included, and so all duplicates were automatically removed before the validation analyses (this was only relevant to mass, length, breadth and thickness) (also see duplicate discussion below).

methods.method_text: Distribution shape assessment: characterising kurtosis and tail shape of morphometric data distributions to interpret OLE performance
trigger_text: The handaxe variables (particularly their upper range) typically displayed greater kurtosis, with records being taken from this long tail, while the EAP data displayed steeper distribution curves and relatively reduced kurtosis

Rivadeneira et al.'s (2009) finding that gradual faunal extinctions (shallow distributions, long tails [low kurtosis]) more often produce OLE CI coverage below 0.95, while sudden extinctions (steep distributions, short tails [high kurtosis]) erred on greater coverages values
OLE estimates are, therefore, likely more accurate if samples display relatively low standard deviations, low kurtosis, and consequently comparatively short distribution tails.
methods.inference_reasoning: The Discussion extensively interprets OLE results in terms of distribution shape characteristics (kurtosis, tail length), implying these were assessed for each dataset. However, no method for measuring or characterising distribution shapes is documented in Methods section. The distribution characterisation appears to be post-hoc interpretation rather than systematic pre-analysis.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: No documented method for assessing distribution shape. Unknown how kurtosis was calculated, what thresholds define 'high' vs 'low' kurtosis, or whether distribution assessment was systematic.
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Moderate - distribution shape claims are interpretive without documented measurement methodology.

methods.method_text: Case study selection methodology: selection of ten archaeological case studies for OLE application
trigger_text: Ten case studies are investigated here to understand how OLE influences our understanding of the archaeological record under diverse assemblage conditions
We present diverse case studies to illustrate how OLE can be used to investigate artefact morphometrics across archaeological periods and material types.
We were keen to include case studies with diverse sample sizes, to explore how estimates may be influenced by the fragmentedness of a dataset.
methods.inference_reasoning: The paper describes wanting 'diverse' case studies across periods, materials, and sample sizes, but no systematic selection methodology is documented. Selection criteria, inclusion/exclusion criteria, or sampling strategy are not specified. Case study selection appears convenience-based (author-contributed datasets) rather than systematic.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: No selection criteria documented. Unknown whether case studies represent systematic sampling or opportunistic availability of author datasets.
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Minor - case studies clearly varied, but selection process affects generalisability claims.

protocols.protocol_text: Handaxe subsampling protocol: random sampling at 5%, 10%, 20%, and 50% of the 500-handaxe assemblage
protocols.verbatim_quote: The replica handaxe assemblage was randomly subsampled at rates of 5%, 10%, 20%, and 50% relative to the total number of records in the assemblage.

protocols.protocol_text: Early Archaic Point subsampling protocol: random sampling at 20%, 30%, 40%, and 50% of the 30-point assemblage
protocols.verbatim_quote: It was also necessary to increase the random sampling percentages for the archaic points such that they started at 20% and increased by 10% until they reached 50%, as sampling rates of 5% and 10% were not sufficient to create a sample large enough to use in the model.

protocols.protocol_text: k-value testing protocol: testing OLE with k values of 5, 10, 20, and 30 records entered into the model
protocols.verbatim_quote: No morphometric studies have tested the robustness of OLE estimates under different data conditions, but previous temporal studies recommend entering c.10 data points into the model (Roberts and Solow, 2003; Solow, 2005; Rivadeneira et al., 2009). We follow this recommendation here, and use the 10 (k) largest or smallest measurements of a given trait, depending on whether the model is applied in the forward or reverse direction. In light of the sometimes considerable artefact samples available to archaeologists, we also assessed the use of k values of 5, 20 and 30 for all validation tests.

protocols.protocol_text: Iteration protocol: 1000 iterations per subsampling percentage and k-value condition, with results presented as median values
protocols.verbatim_quote: One thousand iterations of each process were performed for all subsampling percentages and k, and results were presented as median values across all iterations.

protocols.protocol_text: Duplicate removal protocol: automatic removal of records with equal values before OLE analysis
protocols.verbatim_quote: OLE does not work when records with equal values are included, and so all duplicates were automatically removed before the validation analyses (this was only relevant to mass, length, breadth and thickness).

protocols.protocol_text: Handaxe morphometric data collection protocol: methods described in Key and Lycett (2017)
protocols.verbatim_quote: The methods used to collect these morphometric data are described in Key and Lycett (2017).

protocols.protocol_text: Early Archaic Point data collection protocol: metric data recorded in centimetres from plan-view and profile-view digital images
protocols.verbatim_quote: The metric data were recorded in centimetres from plan-view and profile-view digital images.

protocols.protocol_text: R analysis environment protocol: all analyses undertaken in R version 4.3.0 with scripts available in supplementary information
protocols.verbatim_quote: All analyses were undertaken in 'R' version 4.3.0. The script used to run all validation analyses is available in the supplementary information.

protocols.protocol_text: PCA-based outlier identification protocol: using exploratory principal component analyses to identify and remove outliers from geometric microlith data
trigger_text: two outliers have been removed from the assemblage of phase B after the performance of exploratory principal component analyses (PCAs)
protocols.inference_reasoning: Outlier removal is mentioned as occurring after PCA, but the identification criteria, thresholds for outlier determination, and systematic procedure for outlier detection are not documented. Unknown what defined an 'outlier' in the PCA space or why specifically two cases were removed.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Outlier identification criteria not specified. Unknown PCA-based threshold or visual inspection criteria used. No justification for why these specific two cases were outliers.
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Minor - only affects one case study, but demonstrates undocumented analytical decision.

protocols.protocol_text: Duplicate randomisation procedure: resampling duplicate values from normal distributions to enable OLE analysis
trigger_text: To do this, we resampled each value from a normal distribution, where we used the value itself as the mean, and a very small standard deviation (0.001). We repeated the OLE procedure with randomised values for 1000 iterations, and in our results we show the mean values obtained after the iterations.
protocols.inference_reasoning: The randomisation procedure is described in general terms but lacks specification as a formal protocol. The rationale for the specific SD value (0.001) is not justified. The procedure is documented for microliths but unclear whether applied to other case studies with duplicates.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Rationale for SD=0.001 not justified. Unclear scope of application across case studies. No sensitivity analysis for SD choice documented.
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Minor - randomisation appears reasonable but lacks formal justification.

protocols.protocol_text: Weibull distribution conformity verification: confirming that replica assemblage data conforms to OLE model assumptions
trigger_text: It is also possible to confirm that the complete replica assemblage (sample) conforms to the assumptions of the OLE model (see above).
protocols.inference_reasoning: The paper mentions that distribution conformity CAN be verified and implies it was done ('see above' reference), but no verification results or procedure are documented. Unknown how conformity was tested, what criteria defined adequate fit, or whether all variables were verified.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: No verification procedure documented. Unknown goodness-of-fit test used, acceptance criteria, or results of verification. Critical methodological step referenced but not reported.
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Moderate - distribution assumption is foundational to OLE validity. Verification claimed but not documented.

author_orcids.notes: No ORCIDs visible in plain text extraction. May be present in publisher metadata or online version.

funding.verbatim_text: Collection of capuchin flake data was made possible by a British Academy Fellowship ... to TP
Collection of capuchin flake data was made possible by a ... Leakey Foundation Grant to TP
Excavations to collect the Old Park flake data were funded by a Leakey Foundation Grant to AK

funding.funder_name: London Natural Environment Research Council Doctoral Training Partnership (London NERC DTP)
funding.verbatim_text: Data collection for the Olduvai cleavers was conducted as part of CMR's doctoral research project, funded by the London Natural Environment Research Council Doctoral Training Partnership (London NERC DTP training grant NE/L002485/1)

funding.verbatim_text: TP was supported by grant CEECINST/00052/2021 funded by the Portuguese Foundation for Science and Technology

funding.funder_name: European Social Fund and Agencia Estatal de Investigación (Spain)
funding.purpose: Research position at Universidad de Granada
funding.verbatim_text: PDLP has a Ramón y Cajal Research contract (RYC2020-029506-I) at the Universidad de Granada (Spain) funded by European social fund and the Agencia Estatal de Investigación (Spain)

funding.funder_name: European Commission H2020 Marie Skłodowska-Curie Actions
funding.verbatim_text: ACN was supported by H2020-MSCA–IF–2020 No. 101020631 during the development of this research

data_availability.verbatim_statement: No formal data availability statement. Morphometric data described as drawn from published sources and replica assemblages produced by authors. R scripts stated as available in supplementary information.

machine_actionability.rationale: Data availability implicit via supplementary materials and references to prior publications. No structured repository deposit with persistent identifiers.

data_availability.notes: Case study data referenced from published sources (Key and Lycett 2017, de la Peña and Wadley 2014, etc.). Replica assemblage data appears unpublished but used in validation tests.

code_availability.verbatim_statement: The script used to run all validation analyses is available in the supplementary information.

repositories.name: Supplementary Information
repositories.software_name: R script for OLE validation analyses

repositories.name: Supplementary Information
repositories.software_name: R script for case study tests

machine_actionability.rationale: Code in supplementary materials without DOI or version control. No persistent identifier. R version 4.3.0 mentioned for analyses.

code_availability.notes: Two R scripts mentioned: one for validation analyses, one for case study tests. R version 4.3.0 stated (line 270).

author_contributions.notes: Full CReDIT statement provided. All 12 authors accounted for. AK is corresponding author.

ethics_approval.notes: No ethics statement. Methods paper using published archaeological data and replica artefacts produced by authors. No human subjects research requiring ethics approval.

permits_and_authorizations.notes: No permits explicitly mentioned. Case study data drawn from previously published excavations (Old Park, Boxgrove, Olduvai, Sibudu, etc.) where permits would have been obtained for original excavations. Replica assemblages produced by authors.

preregistration.notes: No preregistration statement. Methods validation paper - preregistration not standard practice for this research type.

materials.description: R script for case study tests
Supplementary Tables 1-3 (confidence interval coverage data, distribution statistics)
Supplementary Figures 1-3 (morphometric distributions for replica assemblages and case studies)

supplementary_materials.notes: Multiple references to supplementary information throughout paper. Includes R scripts, supplementary tables (at least 3), and supplementary figures (at least 3).

references_completeness.notes: References section spans lines 1080-1232. Many references include DOIs but not all. Older references and some book chapters lack DOIs.

F1_pid.rationale: Paper has DOI. Data/code in supplementary lack persistent identifiers.

F2_rich_metadata.rationale: Standard journal metadata. No structured dataset metadata (DataCite, etc.).

F3_pid_in_metadata.rationale: No separate data/code PIDs referenced in metadata.

F4_indexed.rationale: Supplementary materials not indexed in searchable repositories.

A1_protocol.rationale: Paper accessible via standard https. Supplementary via publisher website.

A1_1_open.rationale: Paper is open access (CC BY). Supplementary access unclear without publisher login.

A1_2_auth_when_needed.rationale: No authentication protocol specified for supplementary access.

A2_metadata_persistence.rationale: Data/code metadata not persisted independently of paper.

I1_formal_language.rationale: R scripts use standard programming language. Data formats not specified.

I2_vocabularies.rationale: No FAIR vocabularies or ontologies used for data description.

I3_qualified_references.rationale: Cross-references to other data sources not machine-actionable.

R1_attributes.rationale: Methods described in paper. Supplementary tables provide context.

R1_1_licence.rationale: Paper is CC BY. Code/data licence not explicitly stated.

R1_2_provenance.rationale: Data provenance described narratively but not in machine-readable format.

R1_3_standards.rationale: No domain-specific community standards referenced for data/code.

machine_actionability.rationale: Code in supplementary, not in versioned repository with DOI. No structured metadata. No API access. Human intervention required to access and use materials.

discipline_context.context_rationale: For a 2024 methods paper in archaeology, FAIR expectations are moderate. Code sharing in supplementary is common but repository deposit with DOI increasingly expected. The paper provides more reproducibility infrastructure than typical for the discipline (R scripts shared, R version specified) but falls short of current best practices (no GitHub/Zenodo, no DOIs for code/data).

recommendations: Deposit R scripts in Zenodo or GitHub with DOI
Deposit validation dataset (replica handaxe measurements) in domain repository
Add explicit licence statement for code
Include software DOI or Software Heritage ID
Provide structured metadata for supplementary datasets

extraction_metadata.notes: Plain text extraction. No formal Data Availability Statement present - code availability implicit in methods section. Substantial funding acknowledgement with 8 distinct funding sources. Full CReDIT statement provided. Open access CC BY licence.

pass0_metadata.author_name_format: full names with middle initials where provided
pass0_metadata.notes: Metadata extracted from plain text file. 12 authors identified from title page section. Journal citation includes article number rather than page range (open access format). DOI present in text. Paper classified as methods paper based on focus on OLE method validation.

pass6_infrastructure.notes: Infrastructure extracted from plain text. 8 funding sources identified. Full CReDIT statement. No ORCIDs in text. Code availability via supplementary materials (no DOI). FAIR score 7/16 (minimally FAIR). PID connectivity minimal (paper DOI only).

pass1_claims_evidence.extraction_strategy: Liberal extraction with over-capture. Section-by-section processing: Abstract, Methods, Results, Discussion, Conclusion.
pass1_claims_evidence.implicit_argument_scan: Systematic 4-type scan completed for all core claims. 6 implicit arguments extracted covering methodological assumptions, design assumptions, unstated assumptions, and bridging claims.
pass1_claims_evidence.notes: Methods paper with substantial quantitative validation results. Evidence items focus on CI coverage values, range extension percentages, and specific case study findings. Claims cover methodological validity, sample size recommendations, and archaeological interpretive implications. Implicit arguments address Weibull distribution assumption, replica assemblage representativeness, and interpretation of range extensions.

evidence.rationale: Both describe distribution shape effects on CI coverage, support same claim (C014)

claims.rationale: Theoretical foundation claims forming single argumentative chain about incomplete assemblages and missing extremes
Both interpret Sibudu bipolar core evidence, complementary aspects of same interpretation
Observation (EAP surprise) and explanation (distribution shape) form single interpretive argument

reclassifications.rationale: R version is methodological detail without claim support, moved to project_metadata

cross_reference_updates: E001, E002: Added C021 to supports_claims (after consolidation)
C014: Updated supported_by to reference consolidated E019 only
pass2_rationalization.implicit_argument_review: Systematic review completed. 6 existing implicit arguments cover all 4 types (methodological assumptions, design assumptions, unstated assumptions, bridging claims). No additions needed - implicit arguments appear comprehensive for this methods paper.
pass2_rationalization.notes: Reduction lower than typical 15-20% target because Pass 1 extraction was already fairly lean for this methods paper. The paper has distinct validation and case study sections with non-overlapping evidence. Consolidation opportunities limited to items with truly identical support patterns. E027 (R version) moved to project_metadata as it provides context but doesn't support specific claims.

pass3_explicit_rdmap.extraction_strategy: Liberal extraction of explicit RDMAP items from Methods section. Focus on clearly stated research designs, methods, and protocols with verbatim quotes.
pass3_explicit_rdmap.notes: Methods paper with well-documented methodology. RD001 (validation design) and RD002 (case study design) are the two primary designs. Methods include OLE modelling (M001), random subsampling (M002), CI coverage assessment (M003), and duplicate handling (M004). Protocols cover sampling procedures, parameter testing, iteration specifications, and data collection. All items have explicit status with direct verbatim quotes from Methods section. Cross-references established between designs→methods→protocols and protocols→evidence.

pass4_implicit_rdmap.extraction_strategy: Systematic 4-pattern scan for implicit RDMAP items across all major sections (Abstract, Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion). Focused on procedures mentioned but not documented, and methodological approaches inferred from results.
transparency_gaps_identified: Blind test design rationale not articulated
Sample size-range correlation investigation not stated as design objective
Distribution shape assessment methodology not documented
Case study selection criteria not specified
Outlier identification criteria for microliths not documented
Weibull distribution conformity verification not reported
pass4_implicit_rdmap.notes: Methods paper with relatively good documentation - 30.4% implicit ratio is at lower end of typical 20-40% range. Main gaps are post-hoc analytical interpretations (distribution shape, sample size correlations) and undocumented data cleaning decisions (outlier removal, duplicate handling rationale). Most critical gap is Weibull distribution conformity verification - foundational assumption mentioned but verification not documented.

rationalisation_assessment.research_designs_review: 6 designs represent distinct strategic decisions: validation design (RD001), case study application (RD002), method repurposing (RD003), comparative validation (RD004), blind test rationale (RD-IMP-001), and sample size investigation (RD-IMP-002). Each addresses independent research question that would be assessed separately.
rationalisation_assessment.methods_review: 6 methods represent distinct analytical approaches: OLE modelling (M001), random subsampling (M002), CI coverage (M003), duplicate handling (M004), distribution assessment (M-IMP-001), case study selection (M-IMP-002). No workflow aggregation warranted - each method answers different methodological question.
rationalisation_assessment.protocols_review: 11 protocols specify distinct operational procedures with different parameters. P001/P002 have different sampling percentages for different assemblage sizes. P005/P-IMP-002 are alternative approaches to duplicate handling. P006/P007 apply to different artifact types. No redundancy identified.
consolidation_opportunities_assessed: P001 + P002 (subsampling): Rejected - different parameters for different assemblages
P005 + P-IMP-002 (duplicate handling): Rejected - removal vs randomisation are alternatives
P006 + P007 (data collection): Rejected - different artifact types
RD001 + RD-IMP-001: Rejected - using replicas vs blindness are distinct design rationales

cross_reference_validation.design_method_chain: complete - all methods trace to at least one design
cross_reference_validation.method_protocol_chain: complete - all protocols trace to at least one method

pass5_rdmap_rationalisation.notes: Minimal rationalisation warranted for this well-structured methods paper. The RDMAP extraction from Passes 3-4 was already at appropriate granularity because the paper documents distinct, well-defined methodological components. This is expected for methods validation papers where each procedure has independent assessment value. Zero reduction is appropriate when original extraction was correctly granular rather than over-extracted.
